summary_english: Experimental conditions for preparing lipid compositions, referencing molar ratios in Table 23.
Setup for initial studies comparing LNP delivery efficiency, referencing characteristics summarized in Tables 1A and 1B.
Physicochemical characteristics including size, polydispersity, and encapsulation efficiency for various nanoparticle compounds shown in Tables 1A and 1B.
Bioluminescence study results measuring luciferase expression (Total Flux) over 24 hours, detailed in Table 2.
Comparison of luciferase expression and lipid clearance relative to MC3 standard across multiple LNP formulations, with results in Tables 3A-D and Figure 8.
Organ-specific (liver, lung, spleen, femur) luciferase expression data for sample formulations, detailed in Table 4.
Total flux measured after intramuscular administration of nanoparticle compositions at different dose levels, shown in Table 5A.
Luciferase expression data for additional intramuscularly administered compounds, detailed in Table 5B.
Comparison of relative luciferase flux between intravenous and intramuscular administration routes in Table 6.
Measurement of cytokine induction (IL-6 and IP-10) for selected compounds, shown in Table 7.
Evaluation of complement activation levels (sC5b-9) for specific nanoparticle compositions, detailed in Table 8.
Clinical markers including liver enzymes and white blood cell levels measured after intravenous administration, shown in Table 9.
Characteristics of nanoparticle compositions formulated with hEPO mRNA, detailed in Table 10.
Comparison of hEPO expression and cytokine levels in mice across various LNP formulations and administration routes, shown in Tables 11A-B and referencing Figure 9.
Direct performance comparison between novel compounds and the MC3 standard in Table 12.
Evaluation of hEPO expression, cytokine induction, and residual lipid levels in the liver after 48 hours in rats, detailed in Tables 13, 14, and 15.
Ratios of hEPO expression and lipid accumulation in liver and spleen tissues for rats across different dose levels, detailed in Tables 16, 17, and 18.
Comprehensive assessment of expression, cytokine induction, lipid levels, and clinical chemistry in rats for Compounds 48-50, shown in Table 19.
Analysis of dose-response for hEPO expression in rats, referencing data visualized in Figures 3 through 6.
Presentation of Area Under the Curve (AUC) data for various dosages, referencing Figure 7.
Pharmacokinetic data including hEPO expression and lipid levels in the liver and spleen over 48 hours in rats, shown in Tables 20, 21, and 22.
List of exemplary nanoparticle formulations with varied molar ratios of components provided in Table 23.
Study protocol for evaluating pretreatment effects with dexamethasone and acetaminophen, detailed in Table 24.
Dosing protocol and pretreatment groups for non-human primate (NHP) studies using hEPO mRNA, detailed in Table 25.
Evaluation of pretreatment effectiveness on protein expression over time in primates, referencing Figure 1.
Comprehensive NHP data including hEPO concentration, PK parameters, complement activation, and cytokine induction, detailed in Tables 26 through 29.
Physical characteristics and comparative rodent/NHP expression efficiency for lead compounds, detailed in Tables 30 and 31.
Validation of hEPO expression levels in cynomolgus monkeys, referencing Figure 2.
Pharmacokinetic parameters measured in primates comparing novel formulations to MC3 standard in Table 32.
Characterization of LNPs containing anti-HA antibody mRNA, detailed in Table 33.
Anti-HA antibody expression levels and AUC comparison in Table 34 and referencing Figure 11.
